Survey May Add
New Fraternities
To MU Campus

Hopkins' Omicron Delta Kappa
Circle next week will conduct a
survey of non-fraternity men to
determine whether they think
there is a need for additional
fraternities here or whether
present fraternity chapters offer
sufficient opportunities for those
desiring fraternity affiliations, a
Circle spokesman said Tuesday.
The survey was initiated by
Dean of Students William K.
Morrill, who has been approached by several national
fraternities which desire to establish chapters at Homewood.

Published every Friday during regular sessiuns of The Johns Hopkins
University except during examinations and college holiday periods, by undergraduates of the University. The views expressed in the editorial columns
are not necessarily those of all Board of Control members. Subscription,
$3.50 per year. Address: Box 1230, Homewood. Telephone BE 5-5879.

Escape From Freedom
"Life at a university is an endless exercise in freedom." This is Hopkins' most generous self-plaudit. This
is the theory, but not the practice. It is a theory which
breeds permissiveness—an attitudp which assumes that
tile entering student is mature enough to be governed by
an ideal "Gentleman's Code," that all phases of life should
be on, a live and let live basis, that the proctor merely
provides a hateful symbol to be evaded, and that the giving
of responsibility is of benefit in the maturation process.
The maturation process is disturbing and is the basis
for a rejection of the theory. The transition from high
school .to college is difficult, but given Hopkins' permissiveness, it is more difficult. Any reaction to this situation
necessarily varies with the individual, but there are three
general reactions.
Most students make a good adjustment, and temper
permissiveness with an awareness that they must fulfill
certain obligations. Others abuse their freedom, refuse
to recognize their freedom and suffer academic harm.
Still others initially reject the freedom and seek authority
to guide them, while some escape the early consequences
of an improper reaction to permissiveness and eventually
conclude, like those who initially reject freedom, that it
was not beneficial for them and is prone -to limitation.
Those who abuse freedom reject it because it harms
them. Those who reject it initially do so because they
refuse to exercise it in a situation which permits and
encourages its use and which is founded on the assumption that the reasonable man will not turn freedom into
license. In all cases, they seek to escape freedom.
In escaping, they indicate that, given less than optimum maturity, they become dependent on multifarious
crutches which allow them to evade the vissicitudes of
freedom and the concommitant self-reliance which forces
them to become adults. They indicate their immaturity
and unwillingness to develop independently.
These crutches are, moreover, insidious to others because they have the indirect effect of jeopardizing the
permissive system which some find compatible with their
desires for self-fulfillment. Further, when self-reliance
is surrendered by a few, it may well be given over by
many who see an example of the easier life through props.
The paradox is clear—those who reject freedom do
not, however, want total authority, but merely benevolent
crutches. And yet in surrendering some of their freedom, they tend to surrender most; worse yet, they fail
to recognize the ultimate value of freedom to themselves
and the danger they do to the freedom of those who do
not want crutches or overbearing authority.

Like Nowhere, Man!
Attacked, chided and analyzed, a generation stands
seemingly friendless. Today's college generation has been
variously characterized as "beat," "silent" or "without a
cause."
Lying directly within the range of fire of seedy and
musty dons, criptie and notetaking analysts, socilogically
minded educators, religiously oriented activity creators
and all those who mind other people's business because
their own is too menial and worthless, the generation is
beat(en), and "woe" cry its delighted detractors.
We asked a few articulate undergraduates in all areas
of study, of all ages and-of all backgrounds to give the one
word which best characterizes the most prominent trait
of their generation. From the collection of words, we
have found a pattern.
Our contemporaries think themselves to be spineless
and gutless—without strength or courage. They are, they
say; "cautious," "afraid," "apathetic," "group-minded,"
"lacking courage," "security seeking," 4'complacent,"
"overaided and underworked," "lazy," "disinterested," "bewildered," "frustrated," "undirected," "seeking" and
"waiting." Above all, they are "conformist."
We presume our generation's justified critics would
have us change. Yet such change—when seen as the action of the student leader who dares advocate his opinions
when they are not expedient or popular; of the undergraduate who calls the shots as he sees them; of the
student who avoids the crutches offered and seeks his own
standards; of the imaginative who condones what convention may term "bad"—is hardly given a better reception. We are faced with the dismaying paradox of criticism for not only silence and conformity but also for initiative and non-conformity.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MAR. 6, 1959

Government Heads To Discuss
UN Problems In McCoy Series
HUSBANDS, ANYONE?

United Nations and United
States Government officials will
give a series of lectures at McCoy
College, beginning March 13 on
the question, "Can the United
Nations Meet Today's Challenges?"

It has been alleged that coeds go to college for the sole purpose
of finding husbands. This is, of course, an infamous canard, and
I give fair warning that, small and spongy as I am, anybody
Who says such a dastardly thing when I am around had better
be prepared for a sound thrashing!

Eight talks are scheduled in
this course, which is to be
opened by Sir Leslie Munro, permanent representative to the
United Nations from New Zealand.

(By the Author of"Rally Round the Flag, Boys!"and,
• "Barefoot Boy with Cheek.")

Girls go to college for precisely the same reasons as men do:
to broaden their horizons, to lengthen their vistas, to drink at
the fount of wisdom. But if, by pure chance, while a girl is
engaged in these meritorious pursuits, a likely looking husband
should pop into view, why, what's wrong with that? Eh?
What's wrong with that?
The question now arises, what should a girl look for in a
husband? A great deal has been written on this subject. Some
say character is most important, some say background, some
say appearance, some say education. All are wrong.
.The most important thing—bar none—in a husband is health.
Though be be handsome as Apollo and rich as Croesus, what
good is he if he just lies around all day accumulating bedsores?

Escape From Freedom
"Life at a university is an endless exercise in freedom." This is Hopkins' most generous self-plaudit. This
is the theory, but not the practice. It is a theory which
breeds permissiveness—an attitudp which assumes that
tile entering student is mature enough to be governed by
an ideal "Gentleman's Code," that all phases of life should
be on, a live and let live basis, that the proctor merely
provides a hateful symbol to be evaded, and that the giving
of responsibility is of benefit in the maturation process.
The maturation process is disturbing and is the basis
for a rejection of the theory. The transition from high
school .to college is difficult, but given Hopkins' permissiveness, it is more difficult. Any reaction to this situation
necessarily varies with the individual, but there are three
general reactions.
Most students make a good adjustment, and temper
permissiveness with an awareness that they must fulfill
certain obligations. Others abuse their freedom, refuse
to recognize their freedom and suffer academic harm.
Still others initially reject the freedom and seek authority
to guide them, while some escape the early consequences
of an improper reaction to permissiveness and eventually
conclude, like those who initially reject freedom, that it
was not beneficial for them and is prone -to limitation.
Those who abuse freedom reject it because it harms
them. Those who reject it initially do so because they
refuse to exercise it in a situation which permits and
encourages its use and which is founded on the assumption that the reasonable man will not turn freedom into
license. In all cases, they seek to escape freedom.
In escaping, they indicate that, given less than optimum maturity, they become dependent on multifarious
crutches which allow them to evade the vissicitudes of
freedom and the concommitant self-reliance which forces
them to become adults. They indicate their immaturity
and unwillingness to develop independently.
These crutches are, moreover, insidious to others because they have the indirect effect of jeopardizing the
permissive system which some find compatible with their
desires for self-fulfillment. Further, when self-reliance
is surrendered by a few, it may well be given over by
many who see an example of the easier life through props.
The paradox is clear—those who reject freedom do
not, however, want total authority, but merely benevolent
crutches. And yet in surrendering some of their freedom, they tend to surrender most; worse yet, they fail
to recognize the ultimate value of freedom to themselves
and the danger they do to the freedom of those who do
not want crutches or overbearing authority.

Like Nowhere, Man!
Attacked, chided and analyzed, a generation stands
seemingly friendless. Today's college generation has been
variously characterized as "beat," "silent" or "without a
cause."
Lying directly within the range of fire of seedy and
musty dons, criptie and notetaking analysts, socilogically
minded educators, religiously oriented activity creators
and all those who mind other people's business because
their own is too menial and worthless, the generation is
beat(en), and "woe" cry its delighted detractors.
We asked a few articulate undergraduates in all areas
of study, of all ages and-of all backgrounds to give the one
word which best characterizes the most prominent trait
of their generation. From the collection of words, we
have found a pattern.
Our contemporaries think themselves to be spineless
and gutless—without strength or courage. They are, they
say; "cautious," "afraid," "apathetic," "group-minded,"
"lacking courage," "security seeking," 4'complacent,"
"overaided and underworked," "lazy," "disinterested," "bewildered," "frustrated," "undirected," "seeking" and
"waiting." Above all, they are "conformist."
We presume our generation's justified critics would
have us change. Yet such change—when seen as the action of the student leader who dares advocate his opinions
when they are not expedient or popular; of the undergraduate who calls the shots as he sees them; of the
student who avoids the crutches offered and seeks his own
standards; of the imaginative who condones what convention may term "bad"—is hardly given a better reception. We are faced with the dismaying paradox of criticism for not only silence and conformity but also for initiative and non-conformity.

It has been alleged that coeds go to college for the sole purpose
of finding husbands. This is, of course, an infamous canard, and
I give fair warning that, small and spongy as I am, anybody
Who says such a dastardly thing when I am around had better
be prepared for a sound thrashing!

(By the Author of"Rally Round the Flag, Boys!"and,

Girls go to college for precisely the same reasons as men do:
to broaden their horizons, to lengthen their vistas, to drink at
the fount of wisdom. But if, by pure chance, while a girl is
engaged in these meritorious pursuits, a likely looking husband
should pop into view, why, what's wrong with that? Eh?
What's wrong with that?
The question now arises, what should a girl look for in a
husband? A great deal has been written on this subject. Some
say character is most important, some say background, some
say appearance, some say education. All are wrong.
.The most important thing—bar none—in a husband is health.
Though be be handsome as Apollo and rich as Croesus, what
good is he if he just lies around all day accumulating bedsores?
